subject: Re: [junit] Re: How do I submit code which I think should be added to JUnit?
msgSnippet: Perhaps the right way to go would be to submit JUnit as a JSR. You would loose ownership , but gain acceptance, expertise and support. - Yishay At 09:00 PM
messageBody:
Perhaps the right way to go would be to submit JUnit as a JSR. You would loose "ownership", but gain acceptance, expertise and support.

- Yishay

At 09:00 PM 6/21/2001 +0000, you wrote:
Here's my (admittedly limited) perspective. Lots of people want to
contribute to JUnit. Some people have done significant work. JXUnit
went so far as forking, and Vladimir Bossicard is obviously getting
frustrated (not that I blame him).

1. Erich and I are doing this on really limited resources, and nobody
has ever said, "How can I help?" except Erik Meade. Coming to us with
an offer to make some problem go away is much more likely to get a
positive response than, "Here's some code. Integrate it."

2. JUnit as a political gesture celebrates the ability of programmers
to test their own software. The code and tests must be held to a
higher standard, to demonstrate the techniques necessary to uphold
our end of the bargain.

3. We are new to the open source culture, and we are certain to make
some mistakes. When we do, we need feedback.

4. We don't get to program much, and when we do it is generally in a
very constrainted situation where we have to make lots of
compromises. Our greatest joy in JUnit is a project where we can
engineer at the limits of our ability.

Our long-term goal is to shift primary responsibility for the further
development of JUnit to the community, while retaining the technical
excellence exhibited by junit.framework, extending that level of
refinement to the rest of the codebase, and maintaining our ability
to get together for a couple of days and add cool features.

Immediately, expect any submissions that don't come with extensive
test cases to be unceremoniously bounced. Offers of help with grunge
work will be gratefully accepted.

Kent
